title: ASX flat as media, retail sectors drag
text:
The prediction was as much as 27 per cent lower than the $82 million Southern Cross posted in the first half of the 2019 financial year. The misses were compounded by uncertainties surrounding the viability of its advertising revenue.

"Advertising markets remain short and volatile, and SCA will continue to focus on maximising its market share while maintaining strict cost control across all divisions," Southern Cross said in an announcement.

"Cost discipline remains a core focus, and a series of actions have been taken to mitigate full-year costs in response to adverse market conditions."

Again in the media industry, Nine Entertainment – the publisher of The Australian Financial Review – skidded 6.4 per cent to $1.75 per share as it sewed up its takeover of radio broadcaster Macquarie Media.

The new Nine subsidiary had noted its concern about "subdued" advertising revenue streams in August during its annual results.

But media companies weren't the only sector to find themselves in the firing line, with retailers also getting whacked.

Advertisement

Shares in furniture retailer Nick Scali shed 13.8 per cent to end Tuesday at $6.21 after the company advised the market of "difficult trading conditions" that would see its after-tax profit for the first half of the 2020 financial year come in $8 million short of where it was 12 months before.

"[Net profit after-tax] for the half-year ending 31 December, 2019, will be in the range of [$17 million to $19 million], compared to [$25 million] for the corresponding period in [the financial year 2019]," the company said.

Investors also took the axe to Harvey Norman and JB Hi-Fi, where shares were down 5.9 per cent and 4.5 per cent respectively.

Harvey Norman finished at $3.97 and JB Hi-Fi at $33.06.

Materials take a dive

Global developments, including the retreat of optimism around the US-China trade deal, also weighed on the market.

The partial deal initially boosted stocks on Monday before fading on Tuesday, with the materials sector, in particular, skidding 1 per cent.

Advertisement

BHP declined 1.2 per cent to $36.08, Rio Tinto was down 1.4 per cent to $90.60 and Fortescue Metals fell 3.5 per cent to $8.64.

The miners were accompanied on their slide by oil prices, with Brent down 0.8 per cent to $US58.89. Other commodities like gold, up 0.1 per cent to $1493.98 an ounce, and iron ore, up 0.1 per cent to $797.50 a tonne, travelled in the other direction.

Positives for the share market included the aviation and infrastructure sectors.

Qantas Airways rose 2.9 per cent to $6.69, Sydney Airport climbed 2.2 per cent to $8.37, and Transurban advanced 1.1 per cent to $14.66.

Technology play Nearmap grew 5.9 per cent to $2.68 and telecommunications giant Telstra Corporation – which held its annual shareholder meeting on Tuesday – rose 0.9 per cent to $3.54.
description: Australian shares were unable to capitalise on their positive start to the week, as a series of weak guidance statements from retailers and media companies dominated market news.
